docs.lead_paragraph: Watching a gearhead assemble a motorcycle in 13 one-hour installments might not be most people's idea of riveting television, but to Keith Dressel it is a programming niche that is begging to be exploited. In the increasingly cluttered world of cable television, Mr. Dressel is convinced that there is still plenty of space for his fledgling network, AMP TV. Under the banner ''Life Fully Charged,'' his network is aiming at 18- to 34-year-old men who like hard-driving music, muscle cars and extreme sports. A kind of MTV-meets-Speedvision-meets-ESPN2, his publicist says.

headline.main: To Watch These Programs on Cable, You Have to Find Them First

docs.abstract: New niche television networks, those appealing to, say, martial arts athletes, boxing buffs and wine lovers, are not gaining access they want on cable companies' digital channels but are instead being directed onto video on demand, where viewers cannot find them in their channel surfing but must rather seek them out; cable companies have become more selective about adding networks because of increasing demands on their cable bandwidth; putting programs from new networks into on-demand format frees up valuable bandwidth and helps cable operators distinguish themselves from satellite providers, which have fewer on-demand options; niche networks' lack of exposure makes it extremely difficult to bring in advertisers, who are also skeptical of on-demand format because it allows viewers to fast-forward through ads; on-demand format is growing despite drawbacks; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: DARREL SEIFE felt as if he had lost an old friend. Out near the road, a V-shaped trunk was all that remained of the towering oak tree that had stood at the foot of his driveway since long before his arrival at the house 10 years ago. Where branches once arched high and shadows dappled on the pavement, a stump now sat awkwardly like a giant slingshot. ''At first, it seemed like a good idea,'' Mr. Seife, still in mourning, said of the town officials who had told him they needed to take the tree down because it might not be stable. He could have accepted the responsibility for it and had it braced, but that would have made him liable had it fallen on someone. Still, the empty space in the yard loomed before him, a painful reminder.

headline.main: They're Splendid, Except When They Fall

docs.abstract: Article on financial dilemmas that municipalities in Westchester County, NY, often face over large, treasured trees close to highways and roadways, which could become liabilities for municipalities as well as homeowners when they fall; Greenburgh, Yonkers and some other towns are instituting tree-inspection programs in wake of two fatal accidents and subsequent lawsuits; Greenburgh has increased its liability insurance to $21 million from $4 million, has earmarked about $100,000 for tree removal, inspects trees on daily basis and has removed about 100 trees in last year; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the early middle years of my childhood, roughly between the ages of 5 and 10, my brother and sister and I received Christmas presents from a charity that gave gifts to poor kids. These were the years that my mother was single -- after she divorced my father and before she married my stepfather. My family never had an income that pushed us past the poverty line, but it was in the years my mother was without a husband that we were the poorest, which brought us to the attention of those who gave free Christmas presents to the needy. I don't know precisely where the gifts came from, but each December the gift-givers occupied a storefront that stood empty the rest of the year. By the week before Christmas, the place would be stacked from floor to ceiling with unwrapped presents for kids. We could each choose one thing. I remember the things I chose only as you remember the most singular of life's events, not because the gifts were so extraordinary -- they ran the gamut from Twister to a glittering silver baton to a stuffed bear who had a vinyl patch sewn onto her chest bearing the name Henrietta -- but because, as my siblings and I would later say in voices hushed with a mixture of humiliation and remorse, anguish and dark glee, we got them for free.
docs.abstract: Cheryl Strayed essay on getting charity gifts as child growing up on welfare; says she and husband, as new parents, are more concerned about what they will be able to give their son than about what they will not (M)
docs.snippet: In the early middle years of my childhood, roughly between the ages of 5 and 10, my brother and sister and I received Christmas presents from a charity that gave gifts to poor kids. These were the years that my mother was single -- after she divorced...

docs.lead_paragraph: New York City is facing an unusually disruptive week of union actions including a protest rally outside City Hall and strikes by thousands of child care workers and by aides who care for the elderly and ill at home. The city's largest health care union, 1199/SEIU, has called for a three-day strike beginning tomorrow by 23,000 home-care aides against 11 agencies. The agencies, which rely on state and federal funding, say they can not afford the union's demand for a pay increase to $10 an hour from the current $7, but many agencies still hope to reach a settlement by tomorrow.

headline.main: City Unions Seek Raises; Week of Protest in Works

docs.abstract: New York City's largest health care union, 1199/SEIU, calls for three-day strike by its 23,000 home-care aides against 11 agencies, which say they cannot afford $3-an-hour wage increase demanded by union; city's police, firefighters and teachers plan rally outside City Hall on June 8 to press for large wage increase they seek; child care workers, who have been without contract for 42 months, plan three-day walkout begining on June 9 to press for same 9 percent raise over 27 months that city gave most of its unions in previous round of bargaining three years ago (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR many women and their doctors, the yearly Pap test to detect cervical cancer is considered a necessary ritual. Never mind that several years ago, the American Cancer Society advised women age 30 and older that screening every two to three years was enough if they had already passed three consecutive tests. Or that last year, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists and the government agency that sets standards for preventive screenings followed suit. But many patients and doctors do not know about the new guidelines, and many others do not agree with the recommendations.

headline.main: Pap Wars: Whose Calendar to Believe?

docs.abstract: Confusion among women and many doctors about frequency of recommended Pap smears for cervical cancer discussed; American Cancer Society advises screening every 2-3 years for women over age 30 who have had normal results; American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists follows suit, but many doctors are wary of not testing yearly (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: SINCE Peter Dibble, Stonington's first selectman, was arrested at the end of March for repeated acts of sexual misconduct with a young girl, residents and town officials have tried to find a way to force him out of office. Ten days ago, town officials took the only option they said they had: they paid him $75,000 to resign and agreed to cover his health and life insurance premiums for the next 18 months.

headline.main: Ousted From Office by Way of a Buyout

docs.abstract: Update on Peter Dibble, first selectman in Stonington, Conn, who has pleaded no contest to reckless endangerment charges for repeated acts of sexual misconduct with young girl; Dibble receives suspended 90-day sentence; town officials paid Dibble $75,000 to resign and agreed to cover his health and life insurance premiums for next 18 months; special election is expected to choose his successor; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Please note the crux of the problem in James. H. Hunderfund's explanation of the consequences of rejecting exorbitant school budget increases. Rather than questioning contracted raises and health insurance and pension costs, he is cutting student services in his district. One might look to him and his teachers to make a contribution to their own health insurance and pension costs, as many of us do in this economy. How can he in good conscience exempt himself and his employees from the problem? The administrators who refuse to address today's problems with integrity need to be replaced. Patricia Newmark-Carren Great Neck

headline.main: The People Spoke On School Budgets

docs.lead_paragraph: My anxiety about spending money reared up one day when I was walking down the aisles of a C-Town in the Bronx. I was a few years into the fieldwork for a book I was writing on inner-city poverty, living on less than a quarter of the salary I'd earned at my last proper job. That afternoon, I was trailing my book's main subject, Lolli, as she bought the month's groceries. She was a teenager, pregnant, homeless and already the mother of two children. Her young family subsisted on food stamps and vouchers from the federal subsidy program, WIC. The shield of my judgment rose when she passed right by the C-Town weekly discount flier and made her way down the dirty aisles with her shopping cart. She just grabbed things -- packs of chicken legs and pork chops, bags of sugar and rice, bottles of vegetable oil; in went cans of beans and tins of Spam. I stood, stunned, as she reached for the individual-portion cartons of juice -- with their brightly colored miniature straws -- ignoring the larger, economy-size bottles. No calculation of unit price, no can'ts or shoulds or ought-not-to's, no keen eye to the comparative ounce. By the time her stuffed cart reached the checkout line, my unease was turning into anger. Didn't she know she was poor? I cared deeply for Lolli and had spent months calculating the intricate effort she put into her daily survival. But money is a repository of unprocessed emotion, a symbol not only of one's relationship to the world but also of one's relationship to oneself. Later I realized that part of what I had felt was envy; neither I nor my mother had ever shopped like that. My mother never felt that we could afford it, and my own inability to spend freely stemmed from the immense guilt I felt at benefiting from my parents' deferral of their desires.
docs.abstract: Adrian Nicole LeBlanc essay on dismay at irresponsible spending of teenage mother who uses food stamps without regard to prices or nutritional content; recalls own mother's frugality, and concludes that habit of forgoing momentary pleasures for longer-term goals eludes those who cannot imaging themselves ever not being poor; photo; table of American household expenditures by income (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Ronald Wilson Reagan, a former film star who became America's 40th president, the oldest to enter the White House but imbued with a youthful optimism rooted in the traditional virtues of a bygone era, died yesterday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 93. To a nation hungry for a hero, a nation battered by Vietnam, damaged by Watergate and humiliated by the taking of hostages in Iran, Ronald Reagan held out the promise of a return to greatness, the promise that America would ''stand tall'' again.

headline.main: FOSTERED COLD-WAR MIGHT AND CURBS ON GOVERNMENT

docs.abstract: Ronald Wilson Reagan, former film star who became 40th president, oldest to enter White House, dies at age 93 after living final years in seclusion as he coped with debilitation of Alzheimer's disease; nation battered by Vietnam war and damaged by Watergate was hungry for hero and responded to Reagan's optimism and promise of return to greatness; Reagan lived longer than any US president, and touched hearts of many when he let it be known in handwritten letter to nation than he was suffering from Alzheimer's; died with wife Nancy and children Ron Jr, Patti Davis and Michael at bedside; defeated incumbent Jimmy Carter in 1980 and came into second term with immense popularity, which lasted until he and his administration were plunged into turmoil by Iran-Contra affair; deception and disdain for law undermined Reagan's credibility, weakened his powers of persuasion with Congress and left tenure tainted by scandal; biographical sketch; highlights of his presidency discussed; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: TWO guests settle silently into Adirondack chairs on the white veranda of Canyon Ranch's centerpiece mansion here. Another walks the stone labyrinth for meditation, while another follows the walking trails through the trees. Even the Canadian geese that wander the impossibly green lawn seem calm and contemplative. Now take a deep breath of Berkshire mountain air. It's time to head inside for your 10 a.m. cardiac stress test.

headline.main: The Medical Spa: Mixing Mud Packs and Stress Tests

docs.abstract: Canyon Ranch in Lenox, Mass, is one of about 500 medical spas in US that offer guests medical tests and health and fitness advice to take home, in addition to usual yoga, massage and beauty treatments; photos; most of 9,000 or so spas are still beautification-oriented but fastest-growing segment is wellness spa that has doctors, nurses, nutritionists and exercise physiologists on staff (special section, Women's Health) (M)
